can i read a hard drive from my phone?

Yes, you can, but it is not always as simple as just plugging it in.

Because hard drives (especially older mechanical ones) require more power than a simple thumb drive, you often need specific adapters or external power sources.

Here is the breakdown of what you need based on your device and the drive type.

1. The Hardware You Need
For iPhone (Lightning port)

You need: A Lightning to USB 3 Camera Adapter.

Crucial Detail: You generally cannot use the simple, cheap adapters for a spinning hard drive. You need the official Apple style adapter that has two ports (one for the USB drive and one for a lightning charging cable) because the phone cannot power the drive alone.

For iPhone (USB-C, iPhone 15/16)

You need: A USB-C to USB-A adapter (or just a USB-C cable if your drive is USB-C).

Power: The iPhone 15/16 outputs more power, so it can often run portable SSDs directly. For large mechanical drives, you may still need a powered USB hub.

For Android

You need: A USB OTG (On-The-Go) adapter. This converts your phoneâ€™s charging port (USB-C or Micro-USB) into a standard USB-A port.
+1

Power: Like the iPhone, if you are connecting a mechanical hard drive (HDD), the phone likely won't power it. You will need a USB hub that plugs into the wall to give the drive juice.
+1

2. The "Hidden" Problem: File Formats
Even if you have the right cables, your phone might not "read" the drive if it is formatted for a specific computer.

Format	Android	iPhone	Notes
exFAT	Yes	Yes	Best option. Works on Mac, Windows, and phones.
FAT32	Yes	Yes	Works, but cannot hold individual files larger than 4GB.
NTFS	Read-Only*	No	Windows default. Android can often read it but not write to it. iPhone generally cannot read it at all without complex workarounds.
APFS/HFS+	No	Yes	Mac defaults. Android cannot read these.
Note: Some Android brands (like Samsung) have added NTFS support, but stock Android usually does not support writing to NTFS.

3. Step-by-Step Guide
Connect Power (If using a mechanical drive): If your hard drive is the spinning type (you can hear/feel it vibrating), plug it into a powered USB hub first, or use an adapter that allows you to plug in a charger simultaneously.

Connect to Phone: Plug the adapter into your phone.

Open the App:

iPhone: Open the Files app. Tap "Browse" at the bottom right. Your drive should appear under "Locations."

Android: Open Files by Google (or "My Files" on Samsung). Scroll down to "Storage Devices."

Transfer: You can now copy/paste files between the phone and the drive.

Troubleshooting
Drive lights up but doesn't appear: This is almost always a power issue. The drive has enough power to light the LED, but not enough to spin the disk or transfer data. You need an external power source (like a powered hub).

"Unsupported File System" error: This means the drive is formatted in NTFS (Windows) or APFS (Mac) and your phone doesn't speak that language. You would need to reformat the drive on a computer (which erases all data) to exFAT to use it
